definition: Yuelu district of Changsha city 長沙市|长沙市[Chang2 sha1 shi4], Hunan
high mountain/highest peak of a mountain ridge
surname Yue
foot of a hill
Yuelu district of Changsha city 長沙市|长沙市[Chang2 sha1 shi4], Hunan
Yuelu Academy in Changsha, Hunan, famous ancient academy

sentences.english: President Carter and his wife visit Yuelu Academy.
sentences.chinese: 卡特及夫人蔘觀湖南大學嶽麓書院。

sentences.english: In this season, red Yuelu Mountain is most attractive for visitors.
sentences.chinese: 這個季節，紅葉是嶽麓山最吸引遊人的景緻。

sentences.english: Yuelu Academy is one of the four famous academies in China.
sentences.chinese: 嶽麓書院是中國古代四大書院之一。

sentences.english: In the afternoon, we plan to climb Yuelu Mountain.
sentences.chinese: 下午，我們計劃去爬嶽麓山。

sentences.english: The cole flowers were planted by the Yuelu District Government of Changsha.
sentences.chinese: 長沙嶽麓區政府在湘江邊種下這片美麗的花。

sentences.english: In five area of Changsha City, modern service industry in Yuelu district is in the state falling behind.
sentences.chinese: 在長沙市五區中，嶽麓區現代服務業處於落後狀態。

sentences.english: The tea was planted on Yuelu Mountain locating in the suburb of Changsha city.
sentences.chinese: 產於湖南省長沙市郊的嶽麓山。

sentences.english: In the afternoon, we plan to climb Yuelu Mountain.
sentences.chinese: 在下午，我們打算爬嶽麓山。

sentences.english: I found Yuelu to be absolutely stunning, and the view from the top of the mountain at night was breathtaking.
sentences.chinese: 特別是嶽麓山，站在山頂看風景，讓人心曠神怡。

Prime tortoise of the record bureau, Song dynasty historical encyclopedia of political essays, autobiography, memorials and decrees, compiled 1005-1013 under Wang Qinruo 王欽若|王钦若 and Yang Yi 楊億|杨亿, 1000 scrolls
extant work of a calligrapher

short comment or critical appraisal added at the end of a text, on a painting etc
booklet/brochure/(old) book (made of bamboo strips tied together)
to mark a text with dots and circles/to punctuate
On Yueyang Tower (1045), essay by Song writer Fan Zhongyan 范仲淹[Fan4 Zhong4 yan1]

Rites and Ceremonies, part of the Confucian Classic of Rites 禮記|礼记[Li3 ji4]
Yang Xiong (53 BC-18 AD), scholar, poet and lexicographer, author of the first Chinese dialect dictionary 方言[Fang1 yan2]
